div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: H.B.M.'s CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: Yesterday, Mr Vitt. Dimitri was charged before H. B. M.'a Consoler Conr', Cairo, with assanltiog and attempting to strike Antoine Kahii and Memetallah Bittar, louai snbjeots. Me. Sciortioo repreaented the complaioanla, the defenoi being condocted by Mr. Morris Palier, soliciter.

Jacques Mondolfo wu also oalled and aworn. He statrd that he saw two men fighting in the bar, and défendant trying to separate them. Two polioemen oomiog in eeirud défendant and arrested him. Lo ïking round be saw Bittar strike Mahmoud Ali Bey. Bittar waa then felled, bat rose aod laid abont him with a oh tir. Witneas rose and aeis».d the ohair, fearing hemight be strnok. Kahii came up and told him not to meddle, addiog tbat be waa a dangerona oharaotor, eta, etc ; he then called two polioemen, whom be told to arreat him. Thia they did despi te his protests. After-ward Kahii apologised for his langoage. He absolctely denied the charges made.

Mr. J. Peldmann, oalled for the defenoe,eaid he wu présent the whole lime and saw défendant eeits the ohair from Bittar. Rj'sio Borsa, Italien sobject, cotrahorated ail Mr. Peldmann'a statements and added that he saw Bittar strike Mshmond Bey on the terrace of the Continental Hôtel.
The Conrt then stated that no fnrtber evidenoe wu reqnired. There was no groond for a charge of usanlt or attempted usanlt, and both charges were dismissed.

div.head: AMERICANS IN NUBIA.
div.p: Tho report of tho seasou's work of the Bgyptian oxploring party aontyto Nobia by the University of Chicago, il a reoord ofmoat aystomatio work. 'I ho di,rotor of tho work waa Dr. J. H. Breaatod, a loarned Esyptologiat, and tho party woro oqnippod with thoboat eoientifio appara'ua, ono of tint chiof objoct, of tha work being to ohtain photographe of ovory mono-ment aud insoription. Tho région eoleotod for exploration waa thit lying along the Nile bank from Wady Halfa to Arsooar-, being tho ancient kingdom of Lower Nnhia, and no fower tban eighteen temp'os woro explorod and photo-graphed.

From tho daya of ihc Early Empire tho Fharnobi had eut hungry oyoa on the régions oftbo Upicr Nile. both on acoonnt of its wealtb in gold, ivory, and atrange prodoots and animais, and also ai a reoroitiog gronnd, for, from tho time of the sixtb dynaaty, the backbonoof tho Egyptien Army waathoNnbian, aa now it ia tho Sndacoae. It waa, howovor,

• tho kinga of tho twolfth dynaaty who firat eitablirhed rnlo ovor Nobia, and Dr. Brosated fiond many intoroating reoord» of tbo frontior rolere. In the grotioee at Raar Ibrim thoro ia a acene rep,e*onting tho rocaptnro of the Nubien triboto Tho ammots of the tribnte are givon in manloada, a ratât onnsnal mode of ooontiog. Tho a we havo a thonaand mon beariog ivory, two hondred and fifty ladoo with petfomoa and aromatio wooda. Among the articles of triboto are gold, ivory, ebooy, panthère, honnda, oxen, and cattlo. The total waa two thonaand -^x hondred and aixty-aoven manloada. A trnly largo oarasan. Of the gold-prodnoiog oharaotor of thia région an interoat-ing record ia fjnnd of a govemor who boara tho title "Govemor ot the Gold Cuuntry of Amor," ahowiog tbat tho rogion waa the fl»f of tho great Shoban god.

Tbe great rook-ent tomplo of Rimeses II. at AbooSimbol ia one of tho wondera of lhe worid, rivalling in i ta aonlptnrad halls tho cavee ot B'ephanta. The expodition mado a most thoroogb examination oi thia great bnildiog. Horo a nombor of inscription» of the groatcat importance were lor tbo firat time aoonrately oopied. Tbe record of tho great battle ol Radoab, in wh'cb the Egyptiaua atemmed tho tide of Aaiatio iovader», oovor» (ho walla of une hall. On another ia the acoooot of tho marriago of Rimeaea II. witb tbo daughter of the Hittite Kiog. Dr. Breaatod pointa oot ono notions passage, in whiob tho king prays thst in tho wintor j inrnoy ol tho Hittite» to Bgypt thoy miy not bo hiodarod by "rain or soow." It ie doob fui if tho Egyptiaua who road thia passage oould form any idea of what enow wa», for I havo found it quito impossible to make tho Arabe underatand Ibo nature of ioo or snow. In addition to tho aurvoy of tho temple, a large nombor of rook oot atelo and inscriptions woro oopied and photographed.

Ncxt in importanoe to tho work at Abon Simbel waa that at Amads, whoro tho great eighteonth dynaaty tomplo waa oloarod of robbiab, plnnoed, aud photographed. Ooo veiy ioteresting reoord ho:o found waa the record of ibo oolebration of tho aooond Jobilee of Tbothmoa IV. Of great importance waa the diaoovory of aoyeral inscriptions relating to the latter end of iha relgn of Meoeptab, generaPy regardod aa the Phara h ol tho Bxodos. Tbeie documenta show tbat at the end bl tbis Phirai b'a roign thoro waa great trooble in tho land. Af'or noarly four qiontha1 bard work, tho expédition reached Aasouan, haviog mode a thoroogh arohio dogioal aurvoy if ono of tho moat intoroiting provincei of Egypt. Tbo reaolts will bo of tho groatcat valoo in roator-ing tho oarly hiatory ol tho Uppor Nile province» and tbe whulo work ia a good boginning of 'bo Now World'» exploration of tho Old.

div.head: NATIVES AND EUROI'EANS.
div.p: Tû THE EDITOR OP THE "EOVPTIAN GaZETTE."

Sir,— I rrmark with a oortain amnaoment that Sboikh Ali Yonaacf lue been kindlod to molting beat by "Ottoman," and nowaaaorta that lettora liko tboae ponnod by him and an "onknown Engliahman" writing nndor the "nom do guerre" of "Gaol" aro tho canao and origin of ovoiy epooiea of tronblo in tho body politio. Owing to thom' an Amorioan hae been rade to an Egyptien in a railway train, and thia prodigy ie donbtleae tho firat of a aeriea, portonding naturel oonvnlaiona, sohiams, and I koow not what otber catastrophes.

Bot while tho exoollont and loarned Shaikh ia ready to furniah otch offoot with iU caoae, and to dofond tho whola Egyptien nation— which wae novor oritioiaod—ho haï givon ua no reaaon for auppoaiog that tbo aoU of "gonjaterie" ofion porpotrated at tho oxponBO ofSyrian and Européen ladios by a oortain olaes of native meot with tho opon réprobation of their follow», and haa not explained why none of theae inoidonU haa ovor beon taken up by tha N irions liât press.

Had tho loarned 8hoikh addrosaod aomo of his oo-,eligioniata in regard to any anch occurrence» aa thoaa notifiod by the "Joornal do Caire" and other Fronoh newapapers aa having oooorrod in Calro dnring thepastrix montha, and pointed ont that their condnct waa not only diagracefnl in itaelf but injariona to the fai, famo of their oonotrymen, ho woold havo dono hia duty, aod would bava deaerved well of tho pobli». But whon a young Tunisien ia kncckid about by a Boy fur o'-jeot ing to hia onpleaswt advaooos towarda hia siater, whon Enopoao girla are persoooted in tha Monaky by oortain ill mannered Egyp-riaua, onr oontomporaiy ia ailent Hia thnn-dors are resorvod for Mr. Dunlop or aoy o'her Ute noire of tho day who voDtorea to diffor from the Editor of "Ai Moayad" in matteis politioal.

Now I cannot aooopt Sheikh Youaaef'a view thit tho "noble and soporb" condnot of an Egyptien (namo not givon) who waa reoeotly iuaolted by an Amorioan (onkoowo) in a train, one day, somewhore betwosn Alexandrie o, Port 8'id and Cairo,absolves a oortain olaaa of Bgyptiana from the imputations mide io a former lettor. I aay a certain clan ompha-tioally, for I oaver aoooaed ail Bgypriaos of ill maonera towarda Eiropean womeo, but maio-taioed tha*, tha obtroaive ill manoors of a oortain olaaa of Bgyptian woro latally certain to bo regardad by Ruropoina aa aymptomatio, Theae Buropoaus would oonolodo, from what waa throat npon tboir notioo, that the wholo edooatod olaaa waa ontruatworthy in thoao matière Their ounolu'iin woold bo inaooorato —though naturel—but, ai I pointed ont, the prooossoa by which one arrives at a ounoluiion aro of alight importaooo oompared with the oonoloaion itaelf. I griot the inaoooiauy of ail auoh généralisations ; ooo of ' Al Moayad'a" cootribotora woold havo os believe that ail British ofiviala greot moodirs and other notables pipo in mentb, tboir tiooaers tomed op, hoavan knowa hiw higb, their alothei io diurray, while tboir pet doge add a peooliar saorilegiooanesa to tho ioorbaoity of their maatora. What a aoone, Sir, for a oirioata-riat 11 havo eimo excellent deaigna in my mind'a eyi and ehall ho happy to diapoaa of thom for a oonaidorarion ta aoy Nationalist artiat - of oourao, roplioing the boada of tho native grandoo and tho onontturod Briton by blank ovale. In thia way tho namo cartoon may bo naod ovor aod ovor again—with hoad» aooordiog to taete. Tho pipe, the toroed-op trooaere, and ail tho other proportiea will bo □Dalterable, bot tho dog might bo allowod to vary with hia maator. Thna, if my hypothetical and, I hope, gooerona oartooniat were engagod in a oampaign againat the Ministry of the Intorior ho woold limn the well koowo featorea of Mr. Meohell who woold bo aooompaoied by an Ermont dog of th, pnroit broed. If tho Mioiatry of Finanoo woro ondor ths laab Sir Vincent Corbstt and hia amiable aaohihnnd ooold be held up to poblio oontomoly, and if tho Mioiatry of Elooation woro iuvolvod— but no, Sir I—aftor peroaing what the profession dosoribea aa "aample outtinga" I rimply daro not apooulato aa to whtt might bo tho oharaotor of tho Adviaor'e canine friend. I havo viaions of tho Hoood of the Bankervillés. of tho "Maotho Doog," or of Cerberna bimielf, hia heada and j»w» wroathod in oonformity with the Horatiin description in Nationalist texte, iquatting by Mr. Dunlop's foot and grinning with mnltitadinoua fanga and trille insolence at a petiificd notable.

Bnt to retoro to tho gentleman who w»a inaolted by aomebody aomewhere.When I learn that hia auporb conduot ia "in itaelf a diaproof of the onjuitifiable accusationsdireoted againat the entire Bgyptian peopis" aftor repeating "ad nauaenm moam" thit nobody ovor moant to inaolt or accuse tho wholo Bgyptian poople. I mnat point ont that the logio of the abovo rumark ia on a pa, with that of the Athénien worthy who, boing anxions to Bell hia farm, camo into town with a aolitary briok as a Banralo of tho proporty. Howovor, I am very glad to loarn lhat tho Bgyptian bohavodpolito-ly and v»ry aorry to hoar thit "Al Moayad" thinka thit tho rade Amorioan mnat havo read my lettora. Hopiug that we ahall havo no plagooa or other oalamiriei in oonaequenoe thereuf—I ramiin, etc. "Qael."
